canDoStatements: I can introduce myself with basic personal information
I can ask and answer questions about personal details
I can provide basic information about myself
I can understand simple personal questions
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple (I am, I have, I live)

vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to identify yourself or ask about someone's identity
Usually asked as 'How old are you?'
Used to describe where you are from
Used to describe where you live
Used for forms and official documents
Can refer to mobile or landline phone
Used for someone who is learning
Can refer to any educational institution
Used to describe what languages you know
Used to describe what you like to do
Used to tell when you were born
Used to describe hair color and style
Used to describe your country of origin

vocabulary.example: I need a photo for my passport.

vocabulary.definition: A serious situation needing immediate help

exercises.title: Match Personal Information
exercises.description: Match the personal information word with its definition

exercises.title: Complete Personal Information
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct personal information vocabulary

exercises.title: Personal Information Conversation
exercises.description: Practice asking and answering questions about personal information

scenarios.question: What is your name?
How old are you?
Where are you from?
What do you do?

presentSimple.title: Present Simple for Personal Information
presentSimple.description: Learn to use present simple to talk about yourself
rules: Use 'I am' for identity and characteristics
Use 'I have' for possessions and features
Use 'I live' for location
Use 'I work' or 'I am a' for profession
Use 'I speak' for languages

canDoStatements: I can understand and use basic family vocabulary
I can introduce my family members
I can ask and answer simple questions about family
I can describe basic family relationships
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Possessive adjectives (my, your, his, her, their)

vocabulary.example: My father works in an office.
I have one sister and two brothers.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be older or younger sister

vocabulary.example: My brother is taller than me.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be older or younger brother

vocabulary.example: She has a daughter and a son.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe a female child of any age

vocabulary.example: Their son is five years old.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe a male child of any age

vocabulary.example: My aunt lives in New York.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can also refer to your uncle's wife

vocabulary.example: My uncle drives a red car.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can also refer to your aunt's husband

vocabulary.definition: The child of your aunt or uncle
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be male or female cousin
Usually refers to children under 2 years old

vocabulary.definition: A group of people related by blood or marriage
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can refer to immediate or extended family

vocabulary.example: My grandparents live in the country.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Plural form referring to both grandmother and grandfather
Gender-neutral term for brothers and sisters

vocabulary.definition: People related by blood or marriage
vocabulary.example: I have many relatives in Italy.
vocabulary.usageNotes: General term for extended family members

vocabulary.definition: The wife of your father (not your biological mother)
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used when parents are divorced or separated

vocabulary.definition: The husband of your mother (not your biological father)
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used when parents are divorced or separated

vocabulary.definition: One of two children born at the same time
vocabulary.example: My twin sister looks like me.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Can be twin brother or twin sister

vocabulary.definition: The daughter of your brother or sister
The son of your brother or sister

exercises.title: Match Family Members
exercises.description: Match the family member with their definition

exercises.title: Complete the Sentences
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct family vocabulary

items.sentence: I have one ___ and two brothers.

exercises.title: Family Conversation
exercises.description: Practice asking and answering questions about family

scenarios.question: How many people are in your family?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: There are four people in my family: my mother, my father, my sister, and me.

scenarios.question: What does your mother do?
Do you have any brothers or sisters?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: Yes, I have one sister and one brother.

possessiveAdjectives.title: Possessive Adjectives
possessiveAdjectives.description: Learn to use my, your, his, her, their with family members
rules: Use 'my' for things that belong to you
Use 'your' for things that belong to the person you're talking to
Use 'his' for things that belong to a male
Use 'her' for things that belong to a female
Use 'their' for things that belong to more than one person

canDoStatements: I can understand and use basic color vocabulary
I can describe objects using simple adjectives
I can identify colors in everyday situations
I can use basic adjectives to describe people and things

vocabulary.definition: The color of blood or fire
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe objects that are red in color
Used to describe objects that are blue in color

vocabulary.definition: The color of grass and leaves
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe objects that are green in color
Used to describe objects that are yellow in color
Used to describe objects that are black in color
Used to describe objects that are white in color
Used to describe size of objects or people
Used to describe size of objects or people
Used to describe height of people or objects
Used to describe height of people or objects
Used to describe quality or positive characteristics
Used to describe quality or negative characteristics
Used to describe recently acquired or made items

vocabulary.definition: Having existed for a long time
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to describe items that have existed for a long time

exercises.title: Match Colors and Adjectives
exercises.description: Match the color or adjective with its definition

items.definition: The color of blood or fire

exercises.title: Complete Color Descriptions
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct color or adjective

exercises.title: Color and Adjective Conversation
exercises.description: Practice describing objects using colors and adjectives

scenarios.question: What color is your car?
How tall is your friend?
Is your house big or small?
What do you think of this picture?

basicAdjectives.title: Basic Adjectives and Colors
basicAdjectives.description: Learn to use basic adjectives and colors to describe objects
rules: Use adjectives after 'is' to describe objects
Colors are adjectives that describe appearance
Size adjectives describe how big or small something is
Quality adjectives describe how good or bad something is
Adjectives come after the verb 'to be'

canDoStatements: I can understand and use basic food and drink vocabulary
I can order food and drinks in simple situations
I can describe what I like and don't like to eat
I can ask for basic food items
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Likes and dislikes (I like, I don't like)

vocabulary.definition: A food made from flour and water
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used for breakfast, sandwiches, and meals
Common staple food in many cultures
Includes beef, chicken, pork, and other animal proteins
Healthy protein source from the sea
Common breakfast food and cooking ingredient
Common breakfast drink and cooking ingredient

vocabulary.definition: Hot drink made from coffee beans
vocabulary.example: I drink coffee in the morning.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Popular morning drink, can be hot or cold

vocabulary.definition: Hot drink made from tea leaves
vocabulary.usageNotes: Popular drink, can be hot or cold

vocabulary.definition: Round fruit with red or green skin
vocabulary.example: I eat an apple every day.
I eat an orange for vitamin C.
I use tomatoes in my salad.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used in salads, sauces, and cooking
Versatile vegetable, can be cooked many ways

vocabulary.example: I eat carrots for my eyes.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Good for eyesight, can be eaten raw or cooked

vocabulary.example: I use onions in my cooking.
I like cheese on my pizza.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used in sandwiches, pizza, and cooking

vocabulary.example: I use butter on my bread.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used for cooking and spreading on bread

vocabulary.example: I put sugar in my coffee.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to sweeten food and drinks

vocabulary.definition: White substance that makes food taste better
vocabulary.example: I add salt to my food.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to flavor food, don't use too much

vocabulary.definition: Round food with cheese and toppings

vocabulary.example: I eat hamburgers at the restaurant.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Popular fast food, can have different toppings

vocabulary.example: I eat soup when I'm sick.
I eat cake on my birthday.

vocabulary.definition: Sweet brown food made from cocoa

exercises.title: Match Food and Drinks
exercises.description: Match the food or drink with its definition

items.definition: A food made from flour and water
Round fruit with red or green skin

exercises.title: Complete Food Sentences
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct food or drink vocabulary

exercises.title: Food and Drink Conversation
exercises.description: Practice talking about food preferences and ordering

scenarios.question: What do you like to eat for breakfast?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I like to eat bread and eggs for breakfast.

scenarios.question: What's your favorite drink?
Do you like vegetables?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: Yes, I like carrots and tomatoes.

scenarios.question: What do you eat for dinner?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I eat rice and chicken for dinner.

likesDislikes.title: Likes and Dislikes
likesDislikes.description: Learn to express food preferences using like and don't like
rules: Use 'I like' to express positive preferences
Use 'I don't like' to express negative preferences
Add 's' to like when talking about he/she/it
Use 'Do you like?' to ask about preferences
Use 'What do you like?' to ask for preferences

canDoStatements: I can understand and use basic time vocabulary
I can talk about days of the week and months
I can tell the time in simple situations
I can schedule basic appointments
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple for schedules and routines

vocabulary.definition: The first day of the working week
vocabulary.example: I go to work on Monday.
vocabulary.usageNotes: First day of the week in many countries

vocabulary.definition: The second day of the week
vocabulary.example: I have a meeting on Tuesday.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Second day of the working week

vocabulary.definition: The third day of the week
vocabulary.example: I go to the gym on Wednesday.

vocabulary.definition: The fourth day of the week
vocabulary.usageNotes: Fourth day of the working week

vocabulary.definition: The fifth day of the week
vocabulary.usageNotes: Last day of the working week

vocabulary.definition: The sixth day of the week
The seventh day of the week
vocabulary.usageNotes: Last day of the week, day of rest

vocabulary.definition: The first month of the year
vocabulary.usageNotes: First month, winter in northern hemisphere

vocabulary.definition: The second month of the year
vocabulary.usageNotes: Shortest month, winter in northern hemisphere

vocabulary.definition: The third month of the year
The fourth month of the year
vocabulary.example: It rains a lot in April.

vocabulary.definition: The fifth month of the year
The sixth month of the year
The seventh month of the year
The eighth month of the year
vocabulary.example: I go on vacation in August.

vocabulary.definition: The ninth month of the year
The tenth month of the year
The eleventh month of the year
The twelfth month of the year
The measurement of hours, minutes, and seconds
vocabulary.usageNotes: Used to ask about or tell the time

exercises.title: Match Days and Months
exercises.description: Match the day or month with its definition

items.definition: The first day of the working week
The first month of the year
The measurement of hours, minutes, and seconds

exercises.title: Complete Time Sentences
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct time vocabulary

items.hint: First day of the working week

exercises.title: Time and Schedule Conversation
exercises.description: Practice talking about days, months, and schedules

scenarios.question: What day is it today?
What month is your birthday?
What time do you wake up?
What do you do on weekends?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I rest on Saturday and Sunday.

presentSimple.title: Present Simple for Schedules
presentSimple.description: Learn to use present simple to talk about routines and schedules
examples: I go to bed at 10 o'clock.
rules: Use present simple for regular routines
Use 'on' with days of the week
Use 'in' with months
Use 'at' with specific times
Add 's' to verbs with he/she/it

canDoStatements: I can understand and use basic action verbs
I can describe what I do in daily life
I can talk about simple actions and activities
I can use present simple for routines
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple for daily routines and actions

vocabulary.definition: To move from one place to another
vocabulary.example: I go to work every day.

vocabulary.usageNotes: Used when moving toward the speaker
Moving on foot, slower than running

vocabulary.definition: To put food in your mouth
To take liquid into your mouth
To do a job for money
To look at words and understand them
To make words with a pen or pencil
To use your voice to say words
To look at something for a time
To get something by paying money
To make something easier for someone
To get something with your hands

vocabulary.example: I put the book on the table.

vocabulary.usageNotes: Being alive and existing in a place

exercises.title: Match Basic Verbs
exercises.description: Match the verb with its definition

items.definition: To move from one place to another
To put food in your mouth
To do a job for money

exercises.title: Complete Verb Sentences
exercises.description: Fill in the blanks with the correct verb

items.hint: To move from one place to another
To put food in your mouth
To do a job for money

exercises.title: Daily Activities Conversation
exercises.description: Practice talking about daily activities using basic verbs

scenarios.question: What do you do in the morning?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I wake up, eat breakfast, and go to work.

scenarios.question: What do you do at work?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I work on my computer and help customers.

scenarios.question: What do you do in the evening?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I watch TV, read a book, and go to bed.

scenarios.question: What do you like to do?
scenarios.sampleAnswer: I like to play sports and listen to music.

presentSimple.title: Present Simple for Daily Routines
presentSimple.description: Learn to use present simple to talk about daily activities and routines
examples: I go to work every day.
rules: Use present simple for regular routines
Add 's' to verbs with he/she/it
Use 'do/does' for questions
Use 'don't/doesn't' for negatives
Use time expressions like 'every day', 'always', 'usually'

canDoStatements: I can ask for and give information about shopping and services
I can make simple purchases and handle basic transactions
I can understand prices and basic product information
I can ask for help in shops and service locations
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple, questions with 'how much', 'can I help you'

vocabulary.definition: The amount of money something costs
vocabulary.example: What is the price of this shirt?
vocabulary.usageNotes: Often used with 'how much' in questions

vocabulary.example: There is a 20% discount on all items.

vocabulary.definition: A piece of paper showing what you bought and how much you paid
vocabulary.example: Keep your receipt in case you need to return the item.

vocabulary.definition: A person who handles money in a shop
vocabulary.example: The cashier helped me with my payment.

vocabulary.definition: A small room where you can try on clothes
Money returned when you give back a product
vocabulary.example: I want a refund for this broken item.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Often requires receipt and original packaging

vocabulary.definition: How big or small something is
A company's name for its products
vocabulary.example: I prefer this brand of coffee.

vocabulary.definition: A period when items are sold at reduced prices
vocabulary.example: There's a big sale this weekend.

vocabulary.definition: A person who buys goods or services

canDoStatements: I can ask for and give information about travel and transport
I can understand basic travel information and schedules
I can make simple travel arrangements
I can ask for directions and understand basic instructions
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple for schedules, questions with 'when' and 'where'

vocabulary.definition: A piece of paper that allows you to travel or enter a place
vocabulary.example: I need to buy a train ticket.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Required for most forms of transport

vocabulary.definition: A plan of when things happen
The area where you wait for a train
vocabulary.usageNotes: Common in train and subway stations

vocabulary.definition: The place you are traveling to
An official document for international travel
vocabulary.example: Don't forget your passport for the trip.

vocabulary.definition: Bags and suitcases you take when traveling
vocabulary.example: Please check your luggage at the counter.

vocabulary.definition: A document that allows you to get on a plane
vocabulary.example: Show your boarding pass at the gate.

vocabulary.definition: When something happens later than planned
The way from one place to another
vocabulary.example: What's the best route to the airport?

vocabulary.definition: The money you pay for travel
vocabulary.example: How much is the bus fare?

canDoStatements: I can describe basic health problems and body parts
I can ask for and give simple health information
I can understand basic medical instructions
I can describe how I feel physically
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple for symptoms, 'have' for body parts

vocabulary.definition: When your body temperature is higher than normal
vocabulary.example: The child has a high fever.

vocabulary.definition: A planned meeting with a doctor
vocabulary.example: I need to make a doctor's appointment.

vocabulary.definition: A doctor's written order for medicine
vocabulary.example: The doctor gave me a prescription for antibiotics.

vocabulary.definition: A sign that shows you are sick
vocabulary.example: Coughing is a symptom of a cold.

vocabulary.definition: The part of your neck where food and air pass
vocabulary.usageNotes: Common site of pain and infection

vocabulary.definition: The organ where food is digested
How hot or cold your body is
A substance used to treat illness
vocabulary.example: Take this medicine three times a day.

vocabulary.definition: An unpleasant feeling in your body
vocabulary.example: I have pain in my back.

canDoStatements: I can describe my job and workplace
I can understand basic work-related information
I can ask for and give simple work information
I can describe basic work activities
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple for routines, 'work as', 'work for'

vocabulary.example: My colleague helped me with the project.

vocabulary.definition: The money you earn for your work
A formal meeting to ask questions about a job
vocabulary.example: I have a job interview tomorrow.

vocabulary.definition: A room or building where people work
vocabulary.example: I work in an office downtown.

vocabulary.definition: A gathering of people to discuss work
vocabulary.example: We have a meeting at 2 PM.

vocabulary.definition: The latest time something must be finished
vocabulary.example: The deadline for this project is Friday.

vocabulary.definition: Moving to a higher position at work
vocabulary.example: She got a promotion last month.

vocabulary.definition: A document that lists your work experience
Extra hours worked beyond normal schedule
The person who manages you at work

canDoStatements: I can describe weather conditions and seasons
I can understand weather forecasts and reports
I can talk about seasonal activities and clothing
I can ask about and describe weather changes
cefrMapping.grammarFocus: Present simple for weather, 'it's' for weather conditions

vocabulary.definition: A prediction of what the weather will be like
vocabulary.example: What's the weather forecast for tomorrow?

vocabulary.definition: How hot or cold it is
The amount of water in the air
vocabulary.example: The humidity is very high today.
vocabulary.usageNotes: Affects how hot or cold it feels

vocabulary.definition: Light rain with very small drops
Thick mist that makes it hard to see
vocabulary.example: The fog is very thick this morning.

vocabulary.definition: A thin layer of ice that forms on surfaces
vocabulary.example: There's frost on the grass this morning.

vocabulary.definition: The loud sound that comes with lightning
vocabulary.example: I heard thunder during the storm.

vocabulary.definition: A severe snowstorm with strong winds
A long period with no rain
vocabulary.example: The drought has affected the crops.

canDoStatements: I can describe my hobbies and entertainment preferences
I can talk about leisure activities and interests
I can understand basic information about entertainment
I can ask about and discuss leisure activities

vocabulary.definition: An activity you do for pleasure in your free time

vocabulary.example: I'm going to a concert tonight.

vocabulary.definition: A place where art is displayed
A long fictional story in book form
A funny movie, play, or show
Something you buy to remember a place
vocabulary.example: I bought a souvenir from Paris.

vocabulary.definition: A show or act for an audience
A public display of art or objects
vocabulary.example: There's a photography exhibition at the museum.
